name: The Carneades Argumentation System
tagline: An integrated set of tools for argument (re)construction, evaluation, mapping and interchange
body:
The Carneades argumentation system provides web-based, collaborative
software tools for:

-   summarizing the arguments of a debate in an **argument graph**
-   visualizing, browsing and navigating argument graphs
-   critically evaluating arguments
-   forming opinions, participating in polls and ranking stakeholders by
    the degree to which they share your views
-   obtaining clear explanations, using argument graphs, of the
    different effects of alternative policies in particular cases

# The Carneades Web App

Carneades is now a Web application with a three-tiered
architecture consisting of a relational database backend layer, an
application logic layer and a graphical user interface layer. (An earlier version of Carneades, a desktop application called the
[Carneades
Editor](https://www.wuala.com/tfgordon/Public/Carneades/Releases/carneades-editor-1.0.2.jar),
is still available.

Features:

-   Multi-user Web application, with a three-tier architecture,
    including a relational database backend.
-   Zero configuration and zero administration, with a built-in database
    engine and web server.
-   Can be used locally by a single user, without an Internet
    connection.
-   Automatic argument evaluation, based on ASPIC+ and Dung abstract
    argumentation frameworks. Cyclic argument graphs are handled.
-   Argument maps are represented using Structured Vector Graphics (SVG)
-   Exporting and interchanging argument graphs, in a variety of formats, including our own Carneades Argument Format (CAF) and the Argument Interchange Format (AIF) of the University of Dundee.
-   A rule language for representing argumentation schemes and theories ("knowledge bases") to be used for constructing and reconstructing arguments.

Carneades is open source software licensed using the
[MPL-2.0](http://opensource.org/licenses/MPL-2.0) license. Note:
Previous versions of Carneades were licensed under [European Union
Public License](http://ec.europa.eu/idabc/en/document/7774.html) (EUPL
v1.1).

# Documentation

A [draft user
manual](https://github.com/carneades/carneades/blob/master/doc/manual/out/)
is available in various formats (PDF, HTML, ePub). *Note: This user manual is currently out of date.*

For programmers, online documentation of the [Carneades
APIs](http://carneades.github.com/doc/api) is also available.

# Getting Started

Prerequisites:

-   Version 7 or better of a [Java Runtime Environment (JRE
    7)](http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/donloads/index.html).
-   A recent version of a standards-compliant Web Browser (e.g. Firefox,
    Chrome, Safari).

To download, install and run the Carneades Web Application

1.  Download the latest version of the `carneades-webapp.x.zip` file
    from the
    [releases](https://www.wuala.com/tfgordon/Public/Carneades/Releases)
    folder.
2.  Unzip the `carneades-webapp.x.zip` file.
3.  Change to the `carneades-webapp-x` directory.
4.  Double click on the `carneades-webapp.jar` file or execute the
    following command line:\
     `$ java -jar carneades-webapp.jar`

    **Warning:** Microsoft Windows users may need to take extra steps to
    configure Java and the Carneades application. See [this
    explanation](http://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/forum/windows_7-windows_programs/since-updating-to-windows-7-i-am-unable-to-run-any/b4b2c2fb-8634-4d26-bf76-a27cb7e6cbff)
    from Microsoft.

5.  The server will be start and open the home page of the Carneades
    client in your web browser.
6.  If the home page fails to open, enter this URL into the address bar
    of your web browser:\
     `http://localhost:8080/carneades/#/home`
7.  A list of projects should be shown. To get started, click on the
    link for the "Copyright in the Knowledge Economy" project and follow
    the instructions.
8.  To shutdown the server you may need to end the Java task using your
    task manager, depending on your operating system. If you started the
    server from the command line, you can kill the process with
    Control-C on Unix machines, including Macs. If you started the
    server on a Mac by double clicking on the jar file, you can shutdown
    the server by quitting the "routes\_selfexe" application in the
    usual way, with Command-Q.
